titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of George Chapman, The Gentleman Usher (1606)

publicationStmt.publisher: George Chapman, 1559?-1634 (1559?-1634) The Gentleman Usher. By George Chapman London Printed by V. S. for Thomas Thorppe 1606

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The gentleman usher. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1606. Date first performed: 1602-1603.
LION text converted by Clip and checked against hard copy of STC4978 from EEBO

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Pogio Cynanche Strozza Vincentio Alphonso Sarpego Medice or Mendice Bassiolo Lasso Corteza Margaret Enchanter Iulio Fungus Benevenius Strozza and Vincentio; Omnes 1.Bug Huntsman Servant 2.Bug 2 Page The Guard 1 (Masquer) 2 (Masquer)

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Strozza.
sp.l: Haste nephew, what, a sluggard? Fie for shame,
Shall he that was our morning Cock, turn Owl,
And lock out day light from his drowsy eyes?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Pray pardon me for once, lord uncle, for I will be sworn, I had such a dream this morning: methought one came with a commission to take a Sorrel curtoll, that was stolen from him, wheresoever he could find him. And because I feared he would lay claim to my sorrel curtoll in my stable I ran to the Smith to have him set on his mane again, and his tail presently, that the Commission-man might not think him a curtoll. And when the Smith would not do it, I fell abeating of him, so that I could not wake for my life till I was revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: This is your old valour nephew, that will fight sleeping as well as waking.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: 'slid Aunt, what if my dream had been true: (as it might have been for anything I knew) there is never a smith in Italy, shall make an Ass of me in my sleep, if I can choose.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Well said, my furious nephew: but I see
You quite forget that we must rouse today
The sharp-tusked Bore: and blaze our huntsmanship before the duke.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l:
Forget Lord uncle? I hope not; you think belike
my wits are as brittle as a Beetle, or as skittish as your Barbary Mare: one cannot cry wehre, but straight she cries tihi.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Well guest cousin Hysteron Proteron.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: But which way will the dukes grace hunt today ?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Toward Count Lassos house his Grace will hunt,
Where he will visit his late honoured mistress.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Who Lady Margaret that dear young dame?
Will his antiquity, never leave his iniquity?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Why how now nephew? turned Parnassus lately?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Nassus? I know not: but I would I had all the dukes living for her sake, I would make him a poor duke i'faith.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: No doubt of that, if thou hadst all his living .

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I would not stand dreaming of the matter as I do now.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Why how do you dream nephew?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Marry all last night methought I was tying her shoestring.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What all night tying her shoestring?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Aye that I was, and yet I tied it not neither; for as I was tying it, the string broke methought and then methought having , but one point at my hose, methought , I gave her that to tie her shoo withal.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: A point of much kindness I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Whereupon, in the very nick methought the Count came rushing in, and I ran rushing out, with my heels about my hose for haste.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: So will you leave your dreaming and dispatch?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Mind, not a word more, I will go before and overtake you presently.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: My Lord I fancy not these hunting sports,
When the bold game you follow turns again,
And stares you in the face: let me behold
A cast of Falcons on their merry wings,
Daring the stooped prey, that shifting flies:
Or let me view the fearful Hare or Hind,
Tossed like a music point with harmony
Of well mouthed hounds. This is a sport for Princes,
The other rude Boars yield fit game for Boors.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Thy timorous spirit blinds thy judgment, wife,
Those are most royal sports that most approve
The huntsmans prowess, and his hardy mind.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: My Lord, I know too well your virtuous spirit,
Take heed for Gods love if you rouse the Bore,
You come not near him, but discharge aloof
Your wounding Pistol, or well aimed Dart.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Aye Marry wife this counsel rightly flows
Out of thy bosom, pray thee take less care,
Let Ladies at their tables judge of Bores,
Lords in the field: And so farewell sweet love ;
Fail not to meet me at Earl Lassos house.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Pray pardon me for that: you know I love not
These solemn meetings.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: You must needs, for once
Constrain your disposition; and indeed
I would acquaint you more with Lady Margaret,
For special reason.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Very good, my Lord.
Then I must needs go fit me for that presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I pray thee do, farewell.
Here comes my friend.
Good day my Lord; why does your grace confront
So clear a morning with so cloudy looks ?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Askest thou my griefs, that knowest my desperate love
Curbed by my fathers stern rivality:
Must not I mourn that know not whether yet
I shall enjoy a stepdame or a wife?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: A wife prince, never doubt it; your deserts
And youthful graces have engaged so far ,
The beauteous Margaret, that she is your own.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O but the eye of watchful jealousy
Robs my desires of means to enjoy her favour.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Despair not: there are means enough for you,
Suborn some servant of some good respect,
That is near your choice, who though she needs no wooing,
May yet imagine you are to begin,
Your strange young love suit, and so speak for you,
Bear your kind letters, and get safe access.
All which when he shall do; you need not fear
His trusty secrecy, because he dares not
Reveal escapes, where of himself is Author,
Whom you may best attempt, she must reveal;
For if she loves you, she already knows,
And in an instant can resolve you that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And so she will, I doubt not: would to heaven
I had fit time, even now to know her mind:
This counsel feeds my heart with much sweet hope.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Pursue it then; it will not be hard to effect:
The Duke has none for him, but Medice
That fustian Lord, who in his buckram face,
Bewrays, in my conceit, a map of baseness.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye, , there is a parcel of unconstrued stuff,
That unknown Minion raised to honours height,
Without the help of Virtue, or of Art,
Or (to say true) nay of honest part:
O how she shames my father! he goes like
A Princes footman, in old fashioned silks,
And most times, in his hose and doublet only,
So miserable, that his own few men
Do beg by virtue of his livery;
For he gives none for any service done him,
Or any honour, any least reward.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: It is pity such should live about a Prince:
I would have such a noble counterfeit, nailed
Upon the Pillory, and after, whipped
For his adultery with nobility,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Faith I would fain disgrace him by all means,
As enemy to his base-bred ignorance,
That being a great Lord, cannot write nor read.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: For that, we will follow the blind side of him,
And make it sometimes subject of our mirth.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: See, what news with your Nephew Pogio?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: None good I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Where should I find my Lord Uncle?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What is the huge haste with you?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O ho, you will hunt today .

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I hope I will.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: But you may hap to hop without your hope:for the truth is, Kilbucke is run mad.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Nay, it is true sir: and Kilbucke being run mad, bit Ringwood so by the left buttock, you might have turned your nose in it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Out Ass.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: By heaven you might my Lord: do ye think I lie?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'swounds, might I? let us blanket him my Lord: a blanket here.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord Vincentio, by this rush I tell you for good will: and Venus your brach there, runs so proud, that your Hunts-man cannot take her down for his life.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Take her up fool, thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why sir, he would soon take her down if he could take her up I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: Well said, hammer, hammer.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Nay, good now let us alone, and there is your horse, Gray Strozza too has the staggers, and has struck bay Bettrice, your Barbary mare so, that she goes halting in this fashion, most filthily.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What poison blisters thy unhappy tongue
Evermore braying forth unhappy news,
Our hunting sport is at the best my Lord:
How shall I satisfy the Duke your father,
Defrauding him of his expected sport?
See, see, he comes.

body.stage: Enter Alphonso, Medice, Sarpego, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Is this the copy of the speech you wrote,
Seignior Sarpego?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: It is a blaze of wit poetical,
Read it, brave Duke, with eyes pathetical.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: We will peruse it strait: well met Vincentio,
And good Lord Strozza, we commend you both
For your attendance: but you must conceive,
It is no true hunting we intend today ,
But an inducement to a certain show,
Wherewith we will present our beauteous love ,
And therein we bespeak your company.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: We both are ready to attend your Highness.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: See then, here is a Poem that requires
Your worthy censures; offered if it like
To furnish our intended amorous show:
Read it Uincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Pardon me my Lord,
Lord Medices reading, will express it better.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My patience can digest your scoffs my Lord.
I care not to proclaim it to the world:
I can nor write, nor read; and what of that?
I can both see and hear, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Still are your wits at war:here, read this poem.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The red faced Sun hath firked the flundering shades,
And cast bright ammell on Aurora's brow.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: High words and strange:
Read on Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The busky groves that gag-toothed boars do shroud
With cringle crangle horns do ring aloud.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, I have a speech here worth ten of this, and yet I will mend it too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: How likes Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is strangely good,
No inkhorn ever did bring forth the like,
Could these brave prancing words with Actions spur,
Be ridden thoroughly, and managed right,
It would fright the audience, and perhaps delight.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Doubt you of action sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye , for such stuff.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Then know my Lord, I can both act and teach
To any words; when I in Padua schooled it,
I played in one of Plautus Comedies,
Namely, Curculio, where his part I acted,
Projecting from the poor sum of four lines,
Forty fair actions.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Let us see that I pray.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Your Highness shall command,
But pardon me, if in my actions heat
Entering in post post haste I chance to take up
Some of your honoured heels;

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You had best leave out that action for a thing that I know sir.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Then shall you see what I can do without it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: See see, he hath his furniture and all.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: You must imagine, Lords, I bring good news,
Whereof being princely proud I scour the street
And over-tumble every man I meet.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart if he take up my heels.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Thanks good Seignior Sarpego.
How like you Lords, this stirring action?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: In a cold morning it were good my Lord.
But something harsh upon repletion.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Sir I have ventured, being enjoyed to eat
Three scholars commons, and yet drew it neat.

sp.speaker: Pogio.
sp.l: Come sir, you meddle in too many matters; let us I pray tend on our own show at my lord Lassos.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Doing obeisance then to every lord
I now consort you sir even toto corde.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My lord, away with these scholastic wits,
Lay the invention of your speech on me,
And the performance too; I will play my part,
that you shall say, Nature yields more than Art.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Be it so resolved; unartificial truth
An unfained passion can decipher best.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But it will be hard my lord, for one unlearned.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Unlearned? I cry you mercy sir; unlearned ?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I mean, untaught my lord, to make a speech,
As a pretended Actor, without close,
More gracious than your doublet and your hose.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What, think you son we mean to express a speech
Of special weight without a like attire?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Excuse me then my lord; so stands it well.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Has brought them rarely in, to pageant him.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What; think you lord; we think not of attire?
Can we not make us ready at this age?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Alas my lord, your wit must pardon his.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I hope it will, his wit is pitiful.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I pray stand by my Lord;you are troublesome.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: To none but you; am I to you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Not unto me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why then you wrong me Strozza.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Nay, fall not out my Lords.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: May I not know
What your speech is my Liege?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: None but myself, and the Lord Medice.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, pray my Lord
Let none partake with us .

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No be assured,
But for another cause; a word Lord Strozza,
I tell you true, I fear Lord Medice
Will scarce discharge the speech effectually:
As we go therefore, I will explain to you
My whole intent; that you may second him
If need and his debility require.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Thanks for this grace my Liege.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My Lord; your son.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why how now son? forbear; yet it is no matter
We talk of other business Medice
And come, we will prepare us to our show.

sp.speaker: Stro.Vin.
sp.l: Which as we can, we will cast to overthrow.

body.stage: Enter Lasso, Corteza, Margaret, Bassiolo, Sarpego, two Pages, Bassiolo bare before.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Stand by there, make place.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Say now Bassiolo; you on whom relies
The general disposition of my house,
In this our preparation, for the Duke
Are all our officers at large instructed,
For fit discharge of their peculiar places?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: At large my lord instructed.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Are all our chambers hung? Thinke you our house amply capacious to lodge all the train?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Amply capacious:I am passing glad.
And now then to our mirth and musical show,
Which after supper we intend to endure,
Welcomes chief dainties: for choice cates at home,
Ever attend on Princes; mirth abroad,
Are all parts perfect.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: One I know there is.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: And that is yours.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Well guest in earnest Lord,
I need not er ubescere, to take
So much upon me: That my back will bear.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, he will be perfection itself,
For wording well, and dexterous action too.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: And will these waggish pages, hit their songs?

sp.speaker: 2 Pag.
sp.l: Re mi fa sol la?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: O they are practising; good boys, well done;
But where is Pogio? there you are overshot .
To lay a capital part upon his brain,
Whose absence tells me plainly he will neglect him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O no my Lord, he dreams of nothing else,
And gives it out in wagers, he will excel;
And see, (I told your Lord ) he is come.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How now my Lord, have you borrowed a Snit for me: Seignior Bassiolo, can all say, are all things ready? the Duke is hard by, and little thinks that I will be an Actor i'faith, I keep all close my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: O, it is well done, call all the Ladies in,
Sister and daughter, come, for Gods sake come,
Prepare your courtliest carriage for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Corte
sp.l: And Niece, in any case remember this,
Praise the old man, and when you see him first,
Look me on none but him, smiling and lovingly :
And then, when he comes near, make beisance low,
With both your hands thus moving, which not only
Is as it were courtly, and most comely too,
But speaks (as who should say) come hither Duke;
And yet says nothing, but you may deny.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Well taught sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye , and to much end:
I am exceeding fond to humour him.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Hark, does he come with music? what, and bound?
An amorous device: daughter, observe .

body.stage: Enter Enchanter, with spirits singing; after them, Medice, like Syluanus, next the Duke bound, Vincentio, Strozza, with others.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now let us gull Medice, I do not doubt,
But this attire put on, will put him out.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: We will do our best to that end, therefore mark.

sp.speaker: Ench.
sp.l: Lady, or Princess, both your choice commands.
These spirits and I, all servants of your beauty,
Present this royal captive to your mercy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captive to me a subject .

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye , fair Nymph;
And how the worthy mystery befell
Syluanus here, this wooden god can tell.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now is the time man, speak.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Peace Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'swounds my Lord,
Shall I stand by and suffer him to shame you?
My Lord Medice?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Will you not speak my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: How can I?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But you must speak in earnest:
Would not your Highness have him speak my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Yes, and I will speak, and perhaps speak so,
As you shall never mend: I can I know.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Do then my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Medice, forth.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Goddess, fair goddess, for no less , no less.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No less, no less? no more, no more: speak you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: 'swounds they have put me out.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Laugh your fair goddess.
This nobleman disdains to be your fool.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Vincentio, peace.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'swounds my Lord, it is as good a show:
Pray speak Lord Strozza.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Honourable dame.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Take heed you be not out I pray my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I pray forbear my Lord Vincentio:
How this distressed Prince came thus enthralled,
I must relate with words of height and wonder:
His Grace this morning visiting the woods,
And straying far, to find game for the Chase,
At last, out of a myrtle grove he roused
A vast and dreadful Boar, so stern and fierce,
As if the Fiend fell Cruelty herself
Had come to fright the woods in that strange shape.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Excellent good.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Too good a plague on him.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: The princely Savage being thus on foot,
Tearing the earth up with his thundering hoof,
And with the enraged Aetna of his breath.
Firing the air, and scorching all the woods,
Horror held all us Huntsmen from pursuit,
Only the Duke incensed with our cold fear ,
Encouraged like a second Hercules.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Sounds, too good man.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Pray thee let me alone:
And like the English sign of great Saint George.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Plague of that Simile.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Grave valorous example, and like fire,
Hunted the monster close, and charged so fierce,
That he enforced him (as our sense conceived
To leap for soil into a crystal spring,
Where on the sudden strangely vanishing,
Nymph-like for him, out of the waves arose
Your sacred figure like Diana armed,
And (as in purpose of the beasts revenge)
Discharged an arrow through his Highness breast,
Whence yet no wound or any blood appeared:
With which, the angry shadow left the light:
And this Enchanter with his power of spirits,
Brake from a cave, scattering enchanted sounds,
That struck us senseless, while in these strange bands,
These cruel spirits thus enchained his arms,
And led him captive to your heavenly eyes.
The intent whereof on their report relies.

sp.speaker: En.
sp.l: Bright Nymph, that Boar figured your cruelty,
Chared by love, defended by your beauty.
This amorous Huntsman here, we thus enthralled,
As the attendants on your Graces charms,
And brought him hither by your bounteous hands.
To be released, or live in endless bands.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Daughter, release the Duke: alas my Liege.
What meant your Highness to endure this wrong?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Enlarge him Niece, come dame, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What Madam, shall I arrogate so much?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: His Highness pleasure is to grace you so.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Perform it then sweet love, it is a deed
Worthy the office of your honoured hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Too worthy I confess my Lord for me,
If it were serious: but it is in sport,
And women are fit Actors for such pageants.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Thanks gracious love; why made you strange of this?
I rest no less your captive than before,
For me untying, you have tied me more.
Thanks Strozza for your speech, no thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, thank your son my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: It was very well,
Exceeding well performed on every part,
How say you Bassialo?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Rare I protest my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O, my Lord Medice became it rarely,
Methought I liked his manly being out;
It becomes Noblemen to do nothing well.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Now then will it please your Grace to grace our house,
And still vouchsafe our service further honour.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: Lead us my Lord, we will your daughter lead.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You do not lead, but drag her leaden steps.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: How did you like my speech?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O fie upon it , your Rhetoric was too fine.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Nothing at all:
I hope saint Georges sign was gross enough:
But (to be serious) as these warnings pass,
Watch you your father, I will watch Medice,
That in your love-suit, we may shun suspect:
To which end, with your next occasion, urge
Your love to name the person she will choose,
By whose means you may safely write or meet.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That is our chief business: and see, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord, I only come to say, you are welcome,
And so must say, farewell.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: One word I pray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You needs must presently devise,
What person trusted chiefly with your guard,
You think is aptest for me to corrupt,
In making him a mean for our safe meeting?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My fathers Usher, none so fit,
If you can work him well: and so farewell,
With thanks my good Lord Strozza for your speech.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I thank you for your patience, mocking Lady.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O what a fellow has she picked us out?
One that I would have chosen past all the rest,
For his close stockings only.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: And why not?
For the most constant fashion of his hat?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay then, if nothing must be left unspoke,
For his strict form, thus still to wear his cloak.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Well sir, he is your own, I make no doubt:
For to these outward figures of his mind,
He hath two inward swallowing properties
Of any gudgeons; servile Avarice,
And overweening thought of his own worth,
Ready to snatch at every shade of glory:
And therefore, till you can directly board him,
Waft him aloof with hats, and other favours,
Still as you meet him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well, let me alone,
He that is one man's slave, is free from none.

body.stage: Enter Medice, Corteza a Page with a cuppe of Seeke, Strozza following close.

sp.speaker: Med:
sp.l: Come Lady, sit you here: Page, fill some Sack,
I am to work upon this aged Dame,
To glean from her, if there be any cause
(In loving others) of her Nieces coins
To the most gracious love suite of the Duke:
Here noble Lady, this is healthful drink
After our supper.

sp.speaker: Corteza
sp.l: O, it is that my Lord,
That of all drinks keeps life and soul in me.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Here, fill it Page, for this my worthy love:
O how I could embrace this good old widow.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Now lord, when you do thus, you make me think
Of my sweet husband; for he was as like you;
Even the same words, and fashion: the same eyes,
Manly, and choleric, even as you are just,
And even as kind as you for all the world.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: O my sweet widow, thou dost make me proud.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.l: Nay, I am too old for you.

sp.speaker: Med:
sp.l: Too old, that is nothing,
Come pledge me wench, for I am dry again,
And strait will charge your widowhood fresh i'faith:
Why that is well done.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.l: Now fie on it, here is a draught.

sp.speaker: Med:
sp.l: O, it will warm your blood: if you should sip,
It would make you heart-burnt.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.l: Faith and so they say:
Yet I must tell you, since I plied this gear,
I have been haunted with a whoreson pain here,
And every moon almost with a shrewd fever
And yet I cannot leave it: for thank God,
I never was more sound of wind and limb.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.l: Look you, I warrant you I have a leg,
Holds out as handsomely.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Beshrew my life,
But it is a leg indeed, a goodly limb.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: This is most excellent.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: O that your Niece
Were of as mild a spirit as yourself.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Alas Lord Medice, would you have a girl.
As well seen in behaviour as I?
Ah she is a fond young thing, and grown so proud.
The wind must blow at west still, or she will be angry.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Mass so methink; how coy she is to the duke?
I lay my life she has some younger love .

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Gods me, who should it be?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: If it be any; Page, a little Sack.
If it be any: hark now; if it be,
I know not, by this Sack, but if it be,
Mark what I say, my Lord; I drink tee first.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Well said good widow, much good do thy heart,
So now what if it be?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Well, if it be;
To come to that I said, for so I said,
If it be any, it is the Shrewd young Prince,
For eyes can speak, and eyes can understand.
And I have marked her eyes; yet by this cup,
Which I will only kiss.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: O noble Crone,
Now such a huddle and kettle never was.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: I never yet have seen; not yet I say,
But I will mark her after for your sake.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: And do I pray; for it is passing like;
And there is Strozza, a sly Counsellor
To the young boy: O I would give a limb,
To have their knavery limbed and painted out.
They stand upon their wits and paper learning:
Give me a fellow with a natural wit,
That can make wit of no wit; and wade through
Great things with nothing, when their wits stick fast,
O they be scurvy Lords.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Faith so they be,
Your Lordship still is of my mind in all,
And even so was my husband.

sp.speaker: Mid.
sp.l: Gods my life,
Strozza hath Eavesdropped here, and overheard us.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: They have descried me; what Lord Medice
Courting the lusty widow?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Aye , and why not?
Perhaps one does as much for you at home.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What, choleric man? and toward wedlock too?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: And if he be my Lord; he may do worse.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: If he be not; madam he may do better.

body.stage: Enter Bassiolo with seruants with Rushes, and a Carpet.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: My Lords, and Madam, the Dukes grace entreats you
To attend his new-made Duchess for this night,
Into his presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: We are ready sir.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Come strew this room afresh; spread here this carpet,
Nay quickly man, I pray thee; this way fool,
Lay me it smooth, and Even; look if he will;
This way a little more: a little there.
Hast thou no forecast? flood methinks a man
Should not of meere necessity be an Ass.
Look how he strews here too: Come sir Giles Goosecap,
I must do all myself, lay me them thus:
In fine smooth threaves, look you sir, thus in threaves.
Perhaps some tender Lady will squat here,
And if some standing Rush should chance to prick her,
She would squeak and; spoil the songs that must be sung.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: See where he is; now to him, and prepare
Your familiarity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Save you master Bassiolo,
I pray a word sir; but I fear I let you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No my good Lord, no let.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I thank you sir.
Nay pray be covered; O I cry you mercy,
You must be bare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Ever to you my Lord,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, not to me sir,
But to the fair right of your worshipful place.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: A shame of both your worships.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: What means your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Only to do you right sir,and myself ease.
And what sir, will there be some show tonight ?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: A slender presentation of some music
And some thing else my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is passing good sir,
I will not be over bold to ask the particulars.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Yes, if your Lordship please.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O no good sir,
But I did wonder much; for as methought
I saw your hands at work.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Or else my Lord
Our business would be but badly done.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How virtuous is a worthy man's example?
Who is this throne for pray?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: For my Lords daughter,
Whom the duke makes to represent his duchess.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It will be exceeding fit; and all this room
Is passing well prepared; a man would swear,
That all presentiments in it would be rare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, see if thou canst lay them thus in threaves.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: In threaves do ye call it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye my Lord in threaves.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A pretty term:
Well sir I thank you highly for this kindness,
And pray you always make as bold with me
For kindness more than this, if more may be.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O my Lord this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Sir, it is much.
And now I will leave you sir; I know you are busy.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Faith sir a little.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I commend me to ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: A courteous prince believe it; I am sorry
I was no bolder with him; what a phrase
He used at parting: I commend me too .
I will hate i'faith;

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: Good master Usher, will you dictate to me,
Which is the part precedent of this night-cap,
And which posterior? I do ignorance
How I should wear it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why sir, this I take it
Is the precedent part; Aye , so it is.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.l: And is all well sir think you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Passing well.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why sir come on; the Usher shall be judge:
See master Usher: this same Fungus here,
Your Lords retainer, whom I hope you rule,
Would wear this better Jerkin for the Rush-man,
When I do play the Broom-man; and speak first.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: Why sir, I borrowed it, and I will wear it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: What sir, in spite of your Lords gentleman, Usher :

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: No spite sir, but you have changed twice already,
And now would have it again.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why that is all one sir,
Gentility must be fantastical.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I pray thee Fungus let master Pogio wear it.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: And what shall I wear then?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why here is one, that was a Rush-mans Jerkin, and I pray, were it not absurd then; a Broom-man should wear it?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: Foe, there is a reason, I will keep it sir.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Will sir; then do your office master Usher,
Make him put off his Jerkin; you may pluck
His coat over his cares, much more his Jerkin.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Fungus you had best be ruled.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: Best sir! I care not.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: No sir? I hope you are my Lords retainer.
I need not care a pudding for your Lord:
But spare not, keep it, for perhaps I will play
My part as well in this, as you in that,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well said, master Pogio my Lord shall know it.

body.stage: Enter Corteza, with the Broom-wench, & Rush-wench in their petticotes, clokes ouer them, with hats ouer their head-tyres.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Look master Usher, are these wags well dressed?
I have been so in labour with them truly.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: You have had a very good deliverance, Lady:
How I did take her at her labour there,
I use to gird these Ladies so sometimes.

body.stage: Enter Lasso, with Syluan and a Nymph, a man Bugge, and a woman.

sp.l: I pray my Lord, must not I wear this hair?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I pray thee ask my Usher; Come, dispatch,
The duke is ready: are you ready there?
See master Usher; must he wear this hair?

sp.speaker: 1.Bug.
sp.l: Pray master Usher, where must I come in?
Am not I well for a Bug, master Usher?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: What stir is with these boys here, God forgive me,
If it were not for the credit on it, I would see
Your apish trash afire, ere I would endure this.
But pray good master Usher.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Hence ye Brats.
You stand upon your tire; but for your action
which you must use in singing of your songs,
Exceeding dexterously and full of life.
I hope you will then stand like a sort of blocks,
Without due motion of your hands and heads,
And wresting your whole bodies to your words,
Look to it, you are best; and in; Go; All go in.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Come in my masters;let us be out anon.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: What, are all furnished well?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: All well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: More lights then here, and let loud music sound.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Sound Music.

body.stage: Enter Vincentio, Strozzabaro, Margaret, Corteza, and Cynanche bearing her traine. After her the duke whispering with Medice, Lasso with Bassiolo, &c.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Advance yourself, fair Duchess to this Throne,
As we have long since raised you to our heart,
Better decorum never was beheld,
Than twixt this state and you: And as all eyes
Now fixed on your bright Graces think it fit,
So frame your favour to continue it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord; but to obey your earnest will,
And not make serious scruple of a toy,
I scarce durst have presumed this minutes height.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Usher, cause other music; begin your show.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Sound Consort; warn the Pedant to be ready.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam, I think you will see a pretty show.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: I can expect no less in such a presence.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Lo what attention and state beauty breeds,
Whose moaning silence no shrill herald needs.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Lords of high degree,
And Ladies of low courtesy,
I the Pedant here,
Whom some call schoolmaster,
Because I can speak best,
Approach before the rest.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A very good reason.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: But there are others coming,
Without mask or mumming:
For they are not ashamed,
If need be, to be named,
Nor will they hide their faces,
In any place or places;
For though they seem to come,
Loaded with Rush, and Broom:
The Broom-man you must know,
Is seignior Pogio,
Nephew, as shall appear,
To my Lord Strozza here.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: O Lord, I thank you sir, you grace me much.
And to this noble dame,
Whom I with finger name.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A plague of that fools finger.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: And women will ensue,
Which I must tell you true,
No women are indeed,
But Pages made for need,
To fill up women's places.
By virtue of their faces,
And other hidden graces.
A hall, a hall; whist, still, be mum,
For now with silver song they come.

body.stage: Enter Pogio, Fungus, with the song Broome-maid, and Rush-maid. After which Pogio.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Heroes, and Heroines, of gallant strain,
Let not these Brooms, motes in your eyes remain,
For in the Moon, there is one bears withered bushes:
But we (dear wights) do bear green brooms, green rushes,
Whereof these verdant hair balls ycleped Broom,
Do pierce and enter every Ladies room,
And to prove them high born, and no base trash,
Water with which your physiognomies you wash,
Is but a Broom. And more truth to deliver,
Grim Hercules swept a stable with a river,
The wind that sweeps foul clouds out of the air,
And for you Ladies makes the Welkin fair,
Is but a Broom: and O Dan Titan bright,
Most clerkly called the Scavenger of night,
What art thou, but a very broom of gold?
For all this world not to be cried nor sold;
Philosophy, that passion sweeps from thought,
Is the souls Broom, and by all brave wits sought,
Now if Philosophers but Broom-men are,
Each Broom-man then is a Philosopher.
And so we come (gracing your gracious Graces)
To sweep Cares cobwebs from your cleanly faces.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Thanks good master Broom-man.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: For me Rushman then,
To make Rush ruffle in a verse of ten,
A Rush which now your heels do lie on here.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Cry mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.l: Was whilom used for a pungent spear,
In that odd battle, never fought but twice
(As Homer sings) betwixt the frogs and mice,
Rushes make True-love knots; Rushes make rings,
Your Rush maugre the beard of winter springs
And when with gentle, amorous, lazy limbs,
Each Lord with his fair Lady sweetly swims
On these cool Rushes; they may with these babbles,
Cradles for children make; children for cradles,
And lest some Momus here might now cry push,
Saying our pageant is not worth a Rush,
Bundles of Rushes, lo, we bring along,
To pick his teeth that bites them with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: See, see, that is Lord Medice.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Gods me, my Lord,
Has he picked you out, picking of your teeth?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What pick you out of that?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Not such stale stuff
As you pick from your teeth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Leave this war with Rushes,
Good master pedant; pray forth with your show.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Lo thus far then (brave duke)you see.
Meere entertainment; Now our glee
Shall march forth in Morality:
And this quaint Duchess here shall see
The fault of virgin Nicety,
First wooed with Rural courtesy,
Disburden them, prance on this ground,
And make your Exit with your Round.
Well have they danced as it is meet,
Both with their nimble heads and feet.
Now, as our country girls held off,
And rudely did their lovers scoff;
Our Nymph likewise shall only glance
By your fair eyes, and look askance
Upon her female friend that woos her,
Who is in plain field forced to lose her.
And after them, to conclude all,
The purlue of our Pastoral.
A female bug, and eke her friend,
Shall only come and sing and end.
This Lady and Duchess we conclude.
Fair Virgins must not be too rude:
For though the rural wild and antic,
Abused their loves as they were frantic;
Yet take you in your Ivory clutches,
This noble Duke, and be his Duchess.
Thus thanking all for their tacet,
I void the room, and cry valet.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Generally well, and pleasingly performed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now I resign this borrowed majesty,
Which fate unseemingly on my worthless head,
With humble service to your Highness hands.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Well you became it Lady, and I know
All here could wish it might be ever so.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Here is one says nay to that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Plague on you, peace.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Now let it please your Highness to accept
A homely banquet, to close these rude sports.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I thank your Lordship much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Bring lights, make place.

body.stage: Enter Pogio in his cloke and broome-mans attire.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: How do ye my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: O master broom-man, you did passing well.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Ah you mad slave you! you are a tickling Actor.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I was not out like my Lord Medice.
How did you like me Aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O rarely, rarely.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: O thou hast done a work of memory,
And raised our house up higher by a story.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Friend, how conceit you my young mother here?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Fitter for you my Lord, than for your father.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: No more of that sweet friend, those are bugs words.

body.stage: Medice after the song, whispers alone with his seruant.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thou art my trusty servant and thou knowest,
I have been ever bountiful Lord to thee,
As still I will be: be thou thankful then,
And do me now a service of import.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Any my Lord in compass of my life.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Tomorrow then the Duke intends to hunt,
Where Strozza my despiteful enemy,
Will give attendance busy in the chase,
Wherein (as if by chance, when others shoot
At the wild Boar) do thou discharge at him,
And with an arrow, cleave his cankered heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I will not fail my Lord.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Be secret then.
And thou to me shalt be the dearest of men.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now Vanity and Policy enrich me
With some ridiculous fortune on this Usher.
Where is Master Usher?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Now I come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Besides, good sir, your show did show so well,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Did it indeed my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O sir, believe it;
It was the best fashioned and well ordered thing
That ever eye beheld: and there withal,
The fit attendance by the servants used,
The gentle guise in serving every guest,
In other entertainments; every thing
About your house so sortfully disposed,
That even as in a turn-spit called a Jack.
One vice assists another; the great wheels
Turning but softly, make the less to whir
About their business; every different part
Concurring to one commendable end:
So, and in such conformance, with rare grace,
Were all things ordered in your good lords house.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The most fit simile that ever was.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But shall I tell you plainly my conceit,
Touching the man that I think caused this order?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You note my simile.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Drawn from the turn-spit.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: I see you have me,
Even as in that quaint engine you have seen,
A little man in shreds stand at the window,
And seems to put all things in act about him,
Lifting and pulling with a mighty stir,
Yet adds no force to it, nor nothing does:
So, (though your Lord be a brave Gentleman)
And seems to do this business,
He does nothing;
Some man about him was the festival robe,
That made him show so glorious and divine .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I cannot tell my Lord, yet I should know if any such there were.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Should know quoth you;
I warrant you know: well, some there be
Shall have the fortune to have such rare men,
(Like brave beasts to their Arms) support their state,
When others of as high a worth and breed,
Are made the wasteful food of them they feed:
What state hath your Lord made you for your service ?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: He has been my good Lord, for I can spend
Some fifteen hundred crowns in lands a year,
Which I have gotten since I served him first.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: No more than fifteen hundred crowns a year?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It is so much as makes me live my Lord,
Like a poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, it is pretty well:
But certainly my nature does esteem
Nothing enough for virtue; and had I
The Duke my fathers means, all should be spent,
To keep brave men about me: but good sir,
Accept this simple jewel at my hands,
Till I can work persuasion of my friendship,
With worthier arguments.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No good my Lord,
I can by no means merit the free bounties
You have bestowed besides.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, be not strange,
But do yourself right, and be all one man
In all your actions, do not think but some
Have extraordinary spirits like yourself ,
And will not stand in their society,
On birth and riches: but on worth and virtue,
With whom there is no niceness, nor respect
Of others common friendship; be he poor
Or basely born, so he be rich in soul,
And noble in degrees of qualities,
He shall be my friend sooner than a King.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It is a most kingly judgment in your lordship,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Faith sir I know not, but it is my vain humour.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O, it is an honour in a Nobleman.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You have some lords now so politic and proud,
They scorn to give good looks to worthy men.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O fie upon them; by that light my lord,
I am but servant to a Nobleman,
But if I would not scorn such puppet lords,
Would I were breathless.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You sir? so you may,
For they will cog so when they wish to use men,
With, pray be covered sir, I beseech you sit,
Who is there? wait of Master Usher to the door.
O, these be godly gudgeons:where is the deeds?
The perfect Nobleman?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Away, away, ere I would flatter so,
I would eat rushes like lord Medici.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, well my Lord, would there were more such Princes.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Alas, it were pity sir, they would be gulled
Out of their very skins.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why how are you my lord?

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: Who I, I care not:
If I be gulled where I profess plain love,
It will be their faults you know.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O it were their shames.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well, take my jewel, you shall not be strange,
I love not many words.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: My lord, I thank you, I am of few words too.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is friendly said,
You prove yourself a friend, and I would have you
Advance your thoughts, and lay about for state,
Worthy your vertues: be the Minion
Of some great King or Duke: there is Medici,
The Minion of my Father: O the Father!
What difference is there? but I cannot flatter
A word to wise men.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I perceive your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Your Lordship? talk you now like a friend?
Is this plain kindness?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Is it not my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A palpable flattering figure for men common:
Ah my word I should think, if it were another,
He meant to gull me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why it is but your due.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is but my due: if you will be still a stranger:
But as I wish to choose you for my friend,
As I intend when God shall call my father,
To do I can tell what: but let that pass,
Thus it is not fit; let my friend be familiar,
Use not me Lordship, nor yet call me Lord,
Nor my whole name Vincentio, but vince,
As they call Jacke or Will, it is now in use,
Twixt men of no equality or kindness.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I shall be quickly bold enough my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, see how still you use that coy term, Lord
What argues this, but that you shun my friendship?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay pray say not so.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Who should not say so?
Will you afford me now no name at all?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: What should I call you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, then it is no matter.
But I told you Vince.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why then my sweet Vince.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why so then; and yet still there is a fault,
In using these kind words, without kind deeds:
Pray thee embrace me too.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why then sweet Vince.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why now I thank you, 'sblood shall friends be strange?
Where there is plainness, there is ever truth:
And I will still be plain since I am true:
Come let us lie a little, I am weary.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And so am I, I swear since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You may sir by my faith; and sirrah, hark thee,
What lordship wouldst thou wish to have i'faith,
When my old father dies?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Who I? alas.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O not you, well sir, you shall have none,
You are as coy a piece as your Lords daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Who, my mistress?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Indeed, is she your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I'faith sweet Vince, since she was three year old.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And are not we too friends?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Who doubts of that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And are not two friends one?

sp.speaker: Basis.
sp.l: Even man and wife.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Then what to you she is, to me she should be.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why Vince, thou wouldst not have her?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O not I: I do not fancy any thing like you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay but I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: You do not mean to marry her yourself ?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Take heed now, do not gull me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No by that candle.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Then will I be plain.
Thinke you she dotes not too much on my father?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O yes, no doubt on it.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay, I pray you speak.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: You silly man you, she cannot abide him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why sweet friend pardon me, alas I knew not.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But I do note you are in some things simple,
And wrong yourself too much.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Thsnk you good friend,
For your plain dealing, I do mean so well.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But who saw ever summer mixed with winter?
There must be equal years where firm love is.
Could we two love so well so suddenly
Were we not something equaller in years.
Than he and she are?

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: I cry ye mercy sir, I know we could not, but yet be not too bitter,
Considering love is fearful. And sweet friend,
I have a letter to entreat her kindness
Which if you would convey.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye , if I would sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why faith, dear friend, I would not die requiteless.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Would you not so sir?
By heaven a little thing would make me box you,
Which if you would convey? why not I pray?
Which (friend) thou shalt convey.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Which friend, you shall then.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well friend, and I will then.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And use some kind persuasive words for me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The best I swear that my poor tongue can forge.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye , well said, poor tongue: O it is rich in meekness;
You are not known to speak well? You have won
Direction of the Earl and all his house,
The favour of his daughter, and all Dames
That ever I saw, come within your sight,
With a poor tongue? A plague on your sweet lips.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, we will do our best: And faith my Vince,
She shall have an unwieldy and dull soul,
If she be nothing moved with my poor tongue,
Call it no better; Be it what it will.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well said i'faith; Now if I do not think
It is possible, besides her bare receipt
Of that my Letter, with thy friendly tongue,
To get an answer of it, never trust me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: An answer man? 'sblood make no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: By heaven I think so; now a plague of Nature,
That she gives all to some, and none to others.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: How I endear him to me! Come Vince, rise,
Next time I see her, I will give her this:
Which when she sees, she will think it wondrous strange
Love should go by descent, and make the son
Follow the father in his amorous steppes.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: She needs must think it strange, that never yet saw
I durst speak to her, or had scarce her sight.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well Vince I swear thou shalt both see and kiss her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: Swears my dear friend? by what?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Even by our friendship.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O sacred oath! which, how long will you keep?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: While there be bees in Hybla, or white swans
In bright while the banks of Po
Shall bear brave lilies; or Italian dames
Be called the Bone robes of the world.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is elegantly said: and when I fail,
Let there be found in Hybla hives no bees;
Let no swans swim in bright Meander stream,
Nor lilies spring upon the banks of Po,
Nor let one fat Italian dame be found,
But lean and brawn-fallen; Aye , and scarcely sound.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It is enough, but let us embrace with all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So, now farewell sweet Vince.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Farewell my worthy friend, I think I have him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I had forgot the parting phrase he taught me,
I commend me to ye sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: At your wished service sir:
O fine friend, he had forgot the phrase:
How serious apish souls are in vain form:
Well, he is mine, and he being trusted most
With my dear ioue, may often work our meeting,
And being thus engaged, dare not reveal.

body.stage: Enter Pogio in haste, Strozza following.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Horse, horse, horse, my lord, horse, your father is going ahunting .

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: My Lord horse? you ass you, do ye call my Lord horse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Nay, he speaks buddles still, let us slit his tongue.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Nay good uncle now, 'sblood, what captious merchants you be; so the Duke took me up even now: my lord uncle here , and my old lord Lasso, by heaven you are all too witty for me, I am the veriest fool on you all, I will be sworn.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Therein thou art worth us all, for thou knowest thyself.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: But your wisdom was in a pretty taking last night; was it not I pray?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O, for taking my drink a little? i'faith my Lord, for that you shall have the best sport presently with Madam Corteza
that ever was; I have made her so drunk, that she does nothing but kiss my Lord Medice.
See she comes riding the Duke, she is passing well mounted, believe it.

body.stage: Enter Alphonso, Corteza, Cynanche, Bassiolo first, two women attendants, and hunts-men, Lasso.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Good wench forbear.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: My Lord, you must put forth yourself among Ladies, I warrant you have much in you, if you would show it; see, a cheek a twenty; the body of a George, a good leg still; still a good calf, and not slabby, nor hanging I warrant you; a brawn of a thumb here, and it were a pulled partridge; Niece Meg thou shalt have the sweetest bedfellow on him, that ever called Lady husband; try him you shamefaced babble you, try him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good Madam be ruled.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: What a nice thing it is, my Lord, you must set forth this gear, and kiss her; i'faith you must; get you together and be noughts awhile, get you together.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Now what a merry harmless dame it is!

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: My Lord Medice, you are a right noble man, and; will do a woman right in a wrong matter and need be; pray do you give the duke example upon me; you come a wooing to me now; I accept it.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: What mean you sister?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Pray my Lord away; consider me as I am, a woman.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Lord, how I have whirtled her?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: You come awooing to me now; pray thee Duke mark my Lord Medice, and do you mark me virgin; Stand you aside, my Lord, all, and you; give place; now my Lord put case I be strange a little, yet you like a man put me to it. Come kiss me my Lord, be not ashamed.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Not I Madam, I come not awooing to you.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: It is no matter my Lord, make as though you did and come kiss me; I will not be strange a whit.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Fie sister, you are to blame; pray will you go to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Why, hark you brother.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Do ye think I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I think so truly.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: But are you sure I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Else I would not think so.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: But, I would be glad to be sure on it.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I assure you then.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Why then say nothing; and; I will begone God-be-with-thee lord, duke
I will come again anon.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I hope your Grace will pardon her my liege,
For it is most strange; she is as discreet a dame
As any in these countries, and as sober,
But for this only humour of the cup

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: It is good my Lord sometimes:
Come, to our hunting; now it is time I think.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The very best time of the day, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Then my Lord, I will take my leave till night,
Reserving thanks for all my entertainment,
Till I return; in mean time, lovely dame,
Remember the high state you last presented,
sp.stage: Vin.& St.haue al this while talked togither a prettie way.
sp.l: And think it was not a mere festival show,
But an essential type of that you are
In full consent of all my faculties,
And hark you good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: See now, they whisper
Some private order, (I dare lay my life)
For a forced marriage betwixt my love and father,
I therefore must make sure: and noble friends,
I will leave you all, when I have brought you forth,
And seen you in the chase; meanwhile observe
In all the time this solemn hunting lasts,
My father and his minion Medice,
And note, if you can gather any sign,
That they have missed me, and suspect my being,
If which fall out, send home my Page before.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I will not fail my Lord.

body.stage: Medice whispers with I. Huntsman all this while.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Now take thy time.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: I warrant you my Lord, he shall not scape me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Now my dear Mistress, till our sports intended
end with my absence, I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Bassiolo, attend you on my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now will the sport begin; I think my love
Will handle him, as well as I have done.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Madam, I take my leave, and humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcome good madam; maids wait on my Lady.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So mistress, this is fit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fit sir, why so?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why so? I have most fortunate news for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For me sir? I beseech you what are they?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Merit and Fortune, for you both agree;
Merit what you have, and have what you merit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lord with what Rhetoric you prepare your news!

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I need not; for the plain contents they bear
Uttered in any words, deserve their welcome,
And yet I hope the words will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What, in a letter?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whence is it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: From one that will not shame it with his name.
And that is Lord Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: King of heaven!
Is the man mad?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Mad Madam, why?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O heaven, I muse a man of your importance,
Will offer to bring me a letter thus?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why, why good Mistress, are you hurt in that?
Your answer may be what you will yourself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye , but you should not do it: Gods my life,
You shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, you must answer it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I answer it! are you the man I trusted?
And will betray me to a stranger thus?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: that is nothing, dame, all friends were strangers first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now was there ever woman overseen so,
In a wise man's discretion?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Your brain is shallow, come, receive this letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How dare you say so? when you know so well
How much I am engaged to the duke?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The duke? a proper match: a grave old gentleman:
Has beard at will; and would, in my conceit,
Make a most excellent pattern, for a potter
To have his picture stamped on a Jug.
To keep ale-knights in memory of sobriety.
Here gentle madam, take it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take it sir?
Am I common taker of love letters?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Common? why when received you one before?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, it is no matter; I had thought your care
Of my bestowing, would not tempt me thus
To one I know not; but it is because
You know I dote so much on your direction.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: On my direction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sir, Not on yours.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well mistress, if you will take my advice
At any time, then take this letter now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is strange, I wonder the coy gentleman,
That seeing me so oft, would never speak,
Is on the sudden so far wrapped to write.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It showed his judgment, that he would not speak
Knowing with what a strict and jealous eye
He should be noted; hold, if you love yourself ;
Now will you take this letter? pray be ruled.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, you have such another plaguey tongue,
And yet i'faith I will not.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Lord of heaven,
What, did it burn your hands? hold, hold, I pray,
And let the words within it fire your heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I wonder how the devil, he found you out
To be his spokesman, -- O the duke would thank you,
If he knew how you urged me for his son.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The duke? I have fretted her,
Even to the liver, and had much ado
To make her take it, but I knew it was sure;
For he that cannot turn and wind a woman
Like silk about his finger, is no man,
I will make her answer it too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O here is good stuff.
Hold, pray take it for your pains to bring it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Lady you err in my reward a little,
Which must be a kind answer to this letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay then i'faith, it were best you brought a Priest;
And then your client; and then keep the door.
Gods me I never knew so rude a man.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, you shall answer;I will fetch pen and paper.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Poor Usher, how wert thou wrought to this brake?
Men work on one another for we women,
Nay each man on himself; and all in one
Say; No man is content that lies alone.
Here comes our gulled Squire.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Here Mistress, write.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What should I write?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: An answer to this letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sir, I see no cause of answer in it,
But if you needs will show how much you rule me,
Sit down; and answer it, as you please yourself ,
Here is your paper, lay it fair afore you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Lady, content, I will be your Secretary.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I fit him in this task; he thinks his pen
The Shaft of Cupid, in an amorous letter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Is here no great worth of your answer say you?
Believe it, it is exceedingly well writ.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So much the more unfit for me to answer,
And therefore let your Style and it contend.

sp.speaker: Bassi.
sp.l: Well, you shall see I will not be far short,
Although (indeed) I cannot write so well
When one is by, as when I am alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, a good Scribe must write, though twenty talk, and he talk to them too.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, you shall see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A proper piece of Scribeship there is no doubt;
Some words, picked out of Proclamations,
Or great men's Speeches; or well-selling Pamphlets:
See how he rubs his temples: I believe
His Muse lies in the back-part of his brain,
Which thick and gross, is hard to be brought forward,
What? is it loath to come?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No, not a whit:
Pray hold your peace a little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He sweats, with bringing on his heavy style,
I will ply him still, till he sweat all his wit out,
What man, not yet?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Swoons, you will not extort it from a man,
How do you like the word Endear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O fie upon it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, then I see your judgment: what say you to condole?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O brave! I should make a sweet answer, if I should use no words but of your admittance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well sir, write what you please.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Is model a good word with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Put them together I pray.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So I will I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See, see, see, now it comes pouring down.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I hope you will take no exceptions to believe it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out upon it, that phrase is so run out of breath in trifles, that we shall have no belief at all in earnest shortly. Believe it it is a pretty feather; believe it a dainty Rush; believe it an excellent Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So, so, so, your exceptions sort very collaterally.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Collaterally? there is a fine word now; wrest in that if you can by any means.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I thought she would like the very worst of them all, how think you? do not I write, and hear, and talk too now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By my soul, if you can tell what you write now, you write very readily.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: That you shall see straight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But do you not write that you speak now?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O yes, do you not see how I write it? I can not write when anybody is by me, I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gods my life, stay man;you will make it too long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, if I cannot tell what belongs to the length of a Ladies device i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But I will not have it so long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: If I cannot fit you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O me; how it comes upon him? pre thee be short.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, now I have done, and; now I will read it; your Lordships motive accommodating my thoughts, with the very model of my hearts mature consideration: it shall not be out of my Element to negotiate with you in this amorous duello; wherein I will condole with you, that our project cannot be so collaterally made, as our endeared hearts may very well seem to insinuate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No more: no more; fie upon this.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Fie upon this? he is accursed that has to do with these unsound women, of judgment: if this be not good i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But it is so good, it will not be thought to come from a woman's brain.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: That is another matter

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, I will write myself.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: In Gods name Lady: and yet I will not lose this I warrant you; I know for what Lady this will serve as fit; now we shall have a sweet piece of indictment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How spell you foolish?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: F, oo, l, i, sh; she will presume to indite that cannot spell:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How spell you Usher?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'sblood, you put not in those words together, do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, not together.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: What is betwixt I pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ass the.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ass the? betwixt foolish, and Usher,
Gods my life, foolish Ass the Usher?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay then you are so jealous of your wit: now read all I have written I pray.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I am not so foolish as the Usher would make me: O so foolish as the Usher would make me? Wherein would I make you foolish?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sir, in willing me to believe he loved me so well, being so meere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O, is it so? you may say so indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cry mercy sir, and I will write so too, and; yet my hand is so vile,
Pray thee sit thee down and write as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: With all my heart Lady, what shall I write now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You shall write this sir, I am not so foolish to think you love me, being so meere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So meere a stranger!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And yet I know, love works strangely.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Love works strangely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And therefore take heed, by whom you speak for love.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Speake for love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For he may speak for himself .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: May speak for himself .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not that I desire it,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Desire it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But if he do; you may speed, I confess.

sp.speaker: Basse.
sp.l: Speed I confess.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But let that pass, I do not love to discourage anybody .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Discourage my body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you or he pick out what you can, and; so farewell.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And so fare well. Is this all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye , and he may thank your Sirens tongue that it is so much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: A proper Letter if you mark it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well sir, though it be not so proper as the writer; yet it is as proper as the indicter; Every woman cannot be a gentleman Usher; they that cannot go before, must come behind.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well Lady, this I will carry instantly, I commend me to ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pitiful Usher, what a pretty sleight,
Goes to the working up of everything ?
What sweet variety serves a woman's wit?
We make men sue to us for that we wish.
Poor men; hold out a while; and do not sue,
And spite of Custom we will sue to you.

body.stage: Enter Pogio running in and knocking at Cynanche doore.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O God, how weary I am? Aunt, Madam.
Cynanche, Aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O God, Aunt: O God Aunt: O God.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: What bad news brings this man? where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O Aunt, my Uncle, he is shot.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Shot, aye me!
How is he shot?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why with a forked shaft
As he was hunting, full in his left side.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O me accursed, where is he? bring me, where?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Coming with Doctor Beniuemus,
I will leave you, and go tell my Lord Vincentio.

body.stage: Enter Beniuemus with others, bringing in Strozza with an arrow in his side.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: See the sad sight, I dare not yield to grief,
But force feigned patience to recomfort him:
My Lord, what chance is this? how fares your lordship?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Wounded, and faint with anguish, let me rest.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: A chair.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O Doctor, is it a deadly hurt?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I hope not Madam, though not free from danger.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Why pluck you not the arrow from his side?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We cannot Lady, the forked head so fast
Sticks in the bottom of his solid rib.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: No mean then Doctor rests there to educe it?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This only, my good Lord, to give your wound
A greater orifice, and in sunder break
The pierced rib; which being so near the midriff,
And opening to the region of the heart,
Will be exceeding dangerous to your life.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I will not see my bosom mangled so,
Nor sternly be anatomized alive,
I will rather perish with it sticking still.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O no; sweet doctor think upon some help.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I told you all that can be thought in Art ,
Which since your Lordship will not yield to use,
Our last hope rests in Natures secret aid,
Whose power at length may happily expel it.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Must we attend at deaths abhorred door,
The torturing delays of slavish Nature?
My life is in mine own powers to dissolve:
And why not then the pains that plague my life?
Rise furies, and this fury of my bane,
Assail and conquer; what men madness call:
(That hath no eye to sense, but frees the soul,
Exempt of hope, and fear with instant fate)
Is manliest reason; manliest reason then,
Resolve and rid me of this brutish life,
Hasten the cowardly protracted cure
Of all diseases: King of Physicians, death,
I will dig thee from this Mine of misery.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O hold my Lord, this is no christian part,
Nor yet scarce manly, when your mankind foe,
Imperious death shall make your groans his trumpets
To summon resignation of life's Fort,
To fly without resistance; you must force
A countermine of Fortitude, more deep
Than this poor Mine of pains, to blow him up ,
And spite of him live victor, though subdued:
Patience in torment, is a valour more
Than ever crowned The Alcmenean Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Rage is the vent of torment, let me rise.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Men do but cry, that rage in miseries,
And scarcely beaten children, become cries:
Pains are like women's clamours, which the less
They find men's patience stirred, the more they cease.
Of this it is said, afflictions bring to God,
Because they make us like him, drinking up
Joys that deform us with the lusts of sense,
And turn our general being into soul,
Whose actions simply formed and applied,
Draw all our bodies frailties from respect.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Away with this unmedicinable balm
Of worded breath; forbear friends, let me rest,
I swear I will be bands unto myself .

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: That will become your lordship best indeed.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I will break away, and leap into the Sea.
Or from some Turret cast me headlong down,
To shiver this frail carcass into dust.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O my dear Lord, what unlike words are these,
To the late fruits of your religious Noblesse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Leave me fond woman.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: I will be hewn from hence
Before I leave you; help me gentle Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Have patience good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Then lead me in,
Cut off the timber of this cursed Shaft,
And let the forked pile canker to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Dear Lord, resolve on humble sufferance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I will not hear thee, woman, be content.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O never shall my counsels cease to knock
At thy impatient ears, till they fly in
And salve with Christian patience, Pagan sin.

body.stage: Enter Vincentio with a letter in his hand, Bassiolo.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This is her letter sir, you now shall see
How silly a thing it is in respect of mine,
And what a simple woman she has proved ,
To refuse mine for hers; I pray look here.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Soft sir, I know not, I being her sworn servant,
If I may put up these disgraceful words,
Given of my Mistress, without touch of honour.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Disgraceful words; I protest I speak not
To disgrace her, but to grace myself .

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay then sir, if it be to grace yourself ,
I am content; but otherwise you know,
I was to take exceptions to a King.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Nay, you are in the right for that; but read I pray, if there be not more choice words in that letter, than in any three of Gaeuaras golden epistles, I am a very ass. How think you Vince?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: By heaven no less sir, it is the best thing;
Gods what a beast am I.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Is is no matter,
I can set it together again.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I protest I was ravished: but was it possible she should prefer hers before this?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O sir, she cried fie upon this.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well, I must say nothing, love is blind you know, and can find no fault in his beloved.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, that is most certain.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Give it me: I will have this letter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No good Vince, it is not worth it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I will have it i'faith, here is enough in it to serve for my letters as long as I live; I will keep it to breed on as it were:
But I much wonder you could make her write.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Indeed there were some words belonged to that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How strong an influence works in well placed words,
And yet there must be a prepared love,
To give those words so mighty a command,
Or it were impossible they should move so much:
And will you tell me true?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: In any thing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Does not this Lady love you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Love me? why yes; I think she does not hate me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay but i'faith, does she not love you dearly?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No I protest.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nor have you never kissed her?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Kissed her, that is nothing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But you know my meaning:
Have you not been, as one would say, afore me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Not I, I swear.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O, you are too true to tell.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay be my troth, she has, I must confess,
Used me with good respect, and nobly still,
But for such matters.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Very little more,
Would make him take her maidenhead upon him:
Well friend, I rest yet in a little doubt,
This was not hers.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It was by that light that shines,
And I will go fetch her to you to confirm it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O passing friend.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But when she comes, in any case be bold,
And come upon her with some pleasing thing,
To show you are pleased: however she behaves her,
As for example; if she turn her back,
Use you that action you would do before,
And court her thus; Lady, your back part is as fair to me, as is your fore part.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It will be most pleasing.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye , for if you love
One part above another, it is a sign
You like not all alike, and the worst part
About your Mistress, you must think as fair,
As sweet, and dainty, as the very best,
So much, for so much, and considering too,
Each several limb and member in his kind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: As a man should.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: True, will you think of this?

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: I hope I shall.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But if she chance to laugh,
You must not lose your countenance, but devise
Some speech to show you pleased, even being laughed at.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye , but what speech?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Gods precious man! do something of yourself?
But I will devise a speech.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Inspire him folly.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Or it is no matter, be but bold enough,
