And laugh when she laughs, and it is enough:
I will fetch her to you.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now was there ever such a demi-lance,
To bear a man so clear through thick and thin?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Or hark you sir, if she should steal a laughter
Under her fan, thus you may say, sweet Lady,
If you will laugh and lie down, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And so I were by heaven; how know you that?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: 'slid man, I will hit your very thoughts in these things.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Fetch her sweet friend, I will hit your words I warrant,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Be bold then Vince, and press her to it hard,
A shamefaced man, is of all women barred.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How easily worthless men take worth upon them,
And being over credulous of their own worths,
Do underprize as much the worth of others.
The fool is rich, and absurd riches thinks
All merit is rung out, where his purse chinks.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: My Lord, with much entreaty here is my Lady.
Nay Madam, look not back: why Vince I say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Vince? O monstrous jest!

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: To her for shame.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Lady, your back part is as sweet to me
As all your fore part.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: He missed a little: he said her back part was sweet, when
He should have said fair; but see, she laughs most fitly,
To bring in the the other: Vince, to her again, she laughs.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Laugh you fair Dame?
If you will laugh and be down, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What villainous stuff is here?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Sweet Mistress, of meere grace embolden now
The kind young Prince here, it is only love
Upon my protestation, that thus daunts
His most Heroic spirit: so a while
I will leave you close together; Vince, I say --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O horrible hearing, does he call you Vince?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O Aye , what else? and I made him embrace me,
Knitting a most familiar league of friendship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But wherefore did you court me so absurdly?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Gods me, he taught me, I spake out of him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O fie upon it, could you for pity make him
Such a poor creature? it was abuse enough
To make him take on him such saucy friendship;
And yet his place is great; for he is not only
My fathers Usher, but the worlds beside,
Because he goes before it all in folly.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well, in these homely wiles, must our loves mask,
Since power denies him his apparent right,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But is there no mean to dissolve that power,
And to prevent all further wrong to us,
Which it may work, by forcing Marriage rites,
Betwixt me and the Duke?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: No mean but one,
And that is closely to be married first,
Which I perceive not how we can perform:
For at my fathers coming back from hunting,
I fear your father and himself resolve,
To bar my interest with his present nuptials.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That shall they never do; may not we now
Our contract make, and marry before heaven?
Are not the laws of God and Nature, more
Than formal laws of men? are outward rites,
More virtuous than the very substance is
Of holy nuptials solemnised within?
Or shall laws made to curb the common world,
That would not be contained in form without them,
Hurt them that are a law unto themselves?
My princely love, it is not a Priest shall let us:
But since the eternal acts of our pure souls,
Knit us with God, the soul of all the world,
He shall be Priest to us; and with such rites
As we can here devise, we will express,
And strongly ratify our hearts true vows,
Which no external violence shall dissolve .

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: This is our only mean to enjoy each other:
And, my dear life, I will devise a form
To execute the substance of our minds,
In honoured nuptials. First then hide your face
With this your spotless white and virgin veil:
Now this my scarf I will knit about your arm,
As you shall knit this other end on mine,
And as I knit it, here I vow by Heaven ,
By the most sweet imaginary joys,
Of untried nuptials; by loves ushering fire,
Fore-melting beauty, and loves flame itself ,
As this is soft and pliant to your arm
In a circumferent flexure, so will I
Be tender of your welfare and your will,
As of mine own, as of my life and soul,
In all things, and forever; only you
Shall have this care in fullness, only you
Of all dames shall be mine, and only you
I will court, commend and joy in, till I die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With like conceit on your arm this I tie,
And here in sight of heaven , by it I swear,
By my love to you, which commands my life,
By the dear price of such a constant husband,
As you have vowed to be: and by the joy
I shall embrace by all means to requite you:
I will be as apt to govern as this silk,
As private as my face is to this veil,
And as far from offence, as this from blackness.
I will be courted of no man but you,
In, and for you shall be my joys and woes:
If you be sick, I will be sick, though well:
If you be well, I will be well, though sick:
Yourself alone my complete world shall be,
Even from this hour, to all eternity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is enough, and binds as much as marriage.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I will see in what plight my poor lover stands,
Gods me! he beckons me to have me gone,
It seems he is entered into some good vain:
I will hence, love cureth when he vents his pain.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now my sweet life, we both remember well
What we have vowed shall all be kept entire
Maugre our fathers wraths, danger and death:
And to confirm this, shall we spend our breath?
Be well advised, for yet your choice shall be
In all things as before, as large and free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What I have vowed, I will keep even past my death.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And I: and now in token I dissolve
Your virgin state, I take this snowy veil,
From your much fairer face, and claim the dues
Of sacred nuptials: and now fairest heaven,
As thou art infinitely raised from earth,
Different and opposite, so bless this match,
As far removed from Customs popular sects,
And as unstained with her abhorred respects.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Mistress, away, Pogio runs up and down ,
Calling for Lord Vincentio; come away,
For hitherward he bends his clamorous haste.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Remember love.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Or else forget me heaven.
Why am I sought for by this Pogio?
The Ass is great with child of some ill news,
His mouth is never filled with other sound.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Where is my Lord Vincentio, where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Here he is Ass, what an exclaiming keepest thou?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: 'sblood, my Lord, I have followed you up and down like a Tantalus pig, till I have worn out my hose hereabouts, I will be sworn, and yet you call me Ass still; But I can tell you passing ill news my Lord.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.l: I know that well sir, thou never bringest other; what is your news now, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O Lord, my Lord uncle is shot in the side with an arrow.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Plagues take thy tongue, is he in any danger?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O danger; Aye , he has lain speechless this two hours,
And talks so idly.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Accursed news, where is he, bring me to him.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Yes, do you lead, and I will guide you to him.

body.stage: Enter Strozza; brought in a Chaire, Cynanche, Benenemus, with others.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: How fares it now with my dear Lord and husband?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Come near me wife, I fare the better far
For the sweet food of thy divine advice ,
Let no man value at a little price.
A virtuous woman's counsel, her winged spirit,
Is feathered oftentimes with heavenly words;
And (like her beauty) ravishing, and pure.
The weaker body, still the stronger soul,
When good endevours do her powers apply,
Her love draws nearest man's felicity,
O what a treasure is a virtuous wife,
Discreet and loving, Not one gift on earth,
Makes a man's life so highly bound to heaven ;
She gives him double forces, to endure
And to enjoy; by being one with him,
Feeling his Joys and Griefs with equal sense;
And like the twins Hypocrates reports:
If he fetch sighs, she draws her breath as short:
If he lament, she melts herself in tears:
If he be glad, she triumphs; if he stir,
She moves his way; in all things his sweet Ape:
And is in alterations passing strange.
Himself divinely varied without change:
Gold is right precious; but his price infects
With pride and avarice; Authority lifts
Hats from men's heads; and bows the strongest knees,
Yet cannot bend in rule the weakest hearts;
Music delights but one sense; Nor choice meats
One quickly fades, the other stir to sin;
But a true wife, both sense and soul delights,
And mixeth not her good with any ill;
Her vertues (ruling hearts) all powers command;
All Store without her, leaves a man but poor;
And with her, Poverty is exceeding Store;
No time is tedious with her, her true worth
Makes a true husband think, his arms enfold;
(With her alone) a complete world of gold.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: I wish (dear love) I could deserve as much,
As your most kind conceit hath well expressed:
But when my best is done, I see you wounded;
And neither can recure nor ease your pains.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Cynanche, thy advise hath made me well;
My free submission to the hand of heavem
Makes it redeem me from the rage of pain.
For though I know the malice of my wound
Shoots still the same distemper through my veins,
Yet the Judicial patience I embrace,
(In which my mind spreads her impassive powers
Through all my suffering parts;) expels their frailty;
And rendering up their whole life to my soul,
Leaves me naught else but soul; and so like her,
Free from the passions of my fuming blood.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Would God you were so; and that too much pain.
Were not the reason, you felt sense of none.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Thinkst thou me mad Cynanche? for mad men,
By pains ungoverned, have no sense of pain.
But I, I tell you am quite contrary,
Eased with well governing my submitted pain.
Be cheered then wife; and look not for, in me,
The manners of a common wounded man.
Humility hath raised me to the stars;
In which (as in a sort of Crystal Globes)
I sit and see things hid from human sight.
I, even the very accidents to come
Are present with my knowledge; the seventh day
The arrow head will fall out of my side.
The seventh day wife, the forked head will out.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Would God it would my Lord, and leave you well.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes, the seventh day, I am assured it will:
And I shall live, I know it; I thank heaven,
I know it well; and I will teach my physician,
To build his cares hereafter upon heaven
More than on earthly medicines; for I know
Many things shown me from the opened skies,
That pass all arts. Now my physician
Is coming to me, he makes friendly haste;
And I will well requite his care of me.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: How know you he is coming?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Passing well; and that my dear friend lord Vincentio
Will presently come see me too; I will stay
(My good physician) till my true friend come.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Aye me, his talk is idle; and I fear,
Foretells his reasonable Soul now leaves him.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Bring my Physician in, he is at the door.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Alas, there is no Physician.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: But I know it;
See, he is come.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How fares my worthy Lord?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Good Doctor, I endure no pain at all,
And the seventh day, the arrows head will out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why should it fall out the seventh day my Lord?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I know it; the seventh day it will not fail.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I wish it may, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes, it will be so,
You come with purpose to take present leave,
But you shall stay a while; my Lord Vincentio
Would see you fain and now is coming hither:

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How knows your Lordship? have you sent for him?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: No but it is very true; he is now hard by,
And will not hinder your affairs a whit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How want of rest distempers his light brain?
Brings my Lord any train?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: None but himself.
My nephew Pogio now hath left his Grace.
Good Doctor go, and bring him by his hand,
(Which he will give you) to my longing eyes,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: It is strange, if this be true.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: The Prince I think,
Yet knows not of your hurt.

body.stage: Enter Vincentio holding the Doctors hand.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes wife, too well,
See he is come; welcome my princely friend:
I have been shot my Lord; but the seventh day
The arrows head will fall out of my side,
And I shall live.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I do not fear your life,
But, Doctor, is it your opinion,
That the seventh day the arrow head will out?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: No, it is not his opinion, it is my knowledge:
For I do know it well; and I do wish
Even for your only sake, my noble Lord,
This were the seventh day; and I now were well,
That I might be some strength to your hard state,
For you have many perils to endure:
Great is your danger; great; your unjust ill
Is passing foul and mortal; would to God
My wound were something well, I might be with you,
Nay do not whisper; I know what I say,
Too well for you, my Lord, I wonder heaven
Will let such violence threat an innocent life.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What ere it be, dear friend, so you be well,
I will endure it all; your wounded state
Is all the danger I fear towards me.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Nay, mine is nothing; For the seventh day
This a row head will out, and I shall live,
And so shall you, I think; but very hardly.
It will be hardly, you will scape indeed.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Be as will be; pray heaven your prophecy
Be happily accomplished in yourself,
And nothing then can come amiss to me.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What says my Doctor? thinks he I say true?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: If your good Lordship could but rest a while,
I would hope well.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes, I shall rest I know,
If that will help your judgment.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Yes, it will,
And good my Lord, let us help you in to try.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: You please me much, I shall sleep instantly.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why should the humorous boy forsake the chase?
As if he took advantage of my absence,
To some act that my presence would offend.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I warrant you my Lord, it is to that end:
And I believe he wrongs you in your love.
Children presuming on their parents kindness,
Care not what unkind actions they commit
Against their quiet: And were I as you,
I would affright my son from these bold parts,
And father him as I found his deserts.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I swear I will: and can I prove he aims
At any interruption in my love,
I will interrupt his life.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: We soon shall see,
For I have made Madam Corteza search
With pick-locks, all the Ladies Cabinets
About Earl Lassos house; and if there be
Traffic of love, twixt any one of them,
And your suspected son; it will soon appear,
In some sign of their amorous merchandise;
See where she comes, loaded with Gems and; papers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: See here, my Lord, I have robbed all their Caskets,
Know you this Ring? this Carquanet? this Chain?
Will any of these letters serve your turn?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I know not these things; but come: let me read
some of these letters.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Madam, in this deed
You deserve highly of my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay my Lord Medice, I think I told you
I could do pretty well in these affairs:
O these young Girls engross up all the love
From us, (poor Beldams); but I hold my hand,
I will ferret all the cony-holes of their kindness
Ere I have done with them.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Passion of death!
See, see, Lord Medice, my traitorous son ,
Hath long joyed in the favours of my love :
Woe to the womb that bore him: and my care
To bring him up to this accursed hour,
In which all cares possess my wretched life.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What father, would believe he had a son
So full of treachery to his innocent state?
And yet my Lord, this letter shows no meeting,
But a desire to meet.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Yes, yes, my Lord,
I do suspect they meet; and I believe
I know well where too; I believe I do ;
And therefore tell me; does no creature know,
That you have left the chase thus suddenly?
And are come hither? have you not been seen
By any of these Lovers?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Not by any.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Come then, come follow me; I am persuaded
I shall go near to show you their kind hands.
Their confidence, that you are still a hunting,
Will make your amorous son that stole from thence,
Bold in his love-sports; Come, come, a fresh chase,
I hold this picklock, you shall hunt at view.
What, do they think to scape? An old wives eye
Is a blue Crystal full of sorcery.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: If this be true, the traitorous boy shall die.

body.stage: Enter Lasso, Margaret, Bassiolo going before.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Tell me I pray you, what strange hopes they are
That feed your coy conceits against the Duke,
And are prefered before the assured greatness
His highness graciously would make your fortunes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have small hopes, my Lord; but a desire
To make my nuptial choice of one I love,
And as I would be loath to impair my state;
So I, affect not honours that exceed it.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: O you are very temperate in your choice,
Pleading a judgment past your sex, and years.
But I believe some fancy will be found,
The forge of these gay Glosses: if it be,
I shall decipher what close traitor it is
That is your Agent in your secret plots.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Swoones.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: And him for whom you plot; and on you all
I will revenge thy disobedience,
With such severe correction, as shall fright
All such deluders from the like attempts:
But chiefly he shall smart that is your factor.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O me, accursed!

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Mean time I will cut
Your poor craft short i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Poor craft indeed,
That I, or any others use, for me.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Well Dame, if it be nothing but the jar
Of your unfitted fancy, that procures
Your wilful coyness to my Lord the Duke,
No doubt but Time, and Judgment will conform it
To such obedience, as so great desert
Proposed to your acceptance doth require.
To which end do you counsel her Bassiolo.
And let me see Maid against the Duke's return.
Another tincture set upon your looks
Than heretofore; For be assured at last
Thou shalt consent, or else incur my curse:
Advise her, you Bassiolo.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye , my good Lord;
Gods pity, what an errant Ass was I,
To entertain the Princes crafty friendship?
'sblood, I half suspect, the villain gulled me;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Our Squire I think is startled .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay Lady it is true,
And you must frame your fancy to the Duke,
For I protest I will not be corrupted,
For all the friends and fortunes in the world,
To gull my Lord that trusts me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O sir, now,
You are true too late.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No Lady, not a whit,
'sblood, if you think to make an Ass of me,
May chance to rise betimes; I know it, I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out servile coward, shall a light suspect,
That hath no slenderest proof of what we do,
Infringe the weighty faith that thou hast sworn,
To thy dear friend the Prince that dotes on thee;
And will in pieces cut thee for thy falsehood;

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I care not; I will not hazard my estate,
For any Prince on earth: and I will disclose
The complot to your father, if you yield not
To his obedience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do if thou darest,
Even for thy scraped up living, and thy life,
I will tell my father then, how thou didst woo me
To love the young Prince; and didst force me too,
To take his Letters; I was well inclined,
I will be sworn before, to love the Duke,
But thy vile railing at him, made me hate him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I rail at him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I marry did you sir,
And said he was a pattern for a Potter,
Fit it have his picture stamped on a stone Jug ,
To keep Ale-knights in memory of Sobriety.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: She has a plaguey memory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I could have loved him else; nay, I did love him,
Though I dissembled it, to bring him on,
And I by this time might have been a Duchess;
And now I think on it better: for revenge,
I will have the Duke, and he shall have thy head,
For thy false wit within it, to his love.
Now go and tell my Father, pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why and I will go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go, for Gods sake go, are you here yet?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, now I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is bravely done, farewell: but do you hear sir?
Take this with you besides; the young Prince keeps
A certain letter you had writ for me,
(Endearing, and Condoling, and Mature)
And if you should deny things, that I hope
Will stop your impudent mouth: but go your ways,
If you can answer all this, why it is well.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well Lady, if you will assure me here,
You will refrain to meet with the young Prince,
I will say nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good sir, say your worst,
For I will meet him, and that presently.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Then be content I pray, and leave me out,
And meet hereafter as you can yourselves.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, no sir, no, it is you must fetch him to me,
And you shall fetch him, or I will do your errand.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'swounds what a spite is this, I will resolve
To endure the worst; it is but my foolish fear,
The plot will be discovered: O the gods!
It is the best sport to play with these young dames;
I have dissembled, Mistress, all this while
Have I not made you in a pretty taking?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O it is most good; thus you may play on me;
You cannot be content to make me love
A man I hated till you spake for him,
With such enchanting speeches, as no friend
Could possibly resist: but you must use
Your villainous wit, to drive me from my wits:
A plague of that bewitching tongue of yours;
Would I had never heard your scurvy words.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Pardon dear Dame, I will make amends i'faith,
Thinke you that I will play false with my dear Vince?
I swore that sooner Hybla should want bees,
And Italy bone robes, than I; faith
And so they shall.
Come, you shall meet, and double meet, in spite
Of all your foes, and Dukes that dare maintain them,
A plague of all old doters, I disdain them:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Said like a friend; O let me comb the coxcomb.

body.stage: Enter Alphonso, Medice, Lasso, Cortezza aboue .

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Here is the place will do the deed i'faith;
This Duke will show thee how youth puts down age,
Aye and perhaps how youth does put down youth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: If I shall see my love in any sort
Prevented, or abused, the abuser dies.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I hope there is no such intent my Liege,
For sad as death should I be to behold it.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: You must not be too confident my Lord,
Or in your daughter or in them that guard her.
The Prince is politic, and envies his Father:
And though not for himself, nor any good
Intended to your daughter, yet because
He knows it would kill his father, he would seek her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Whist, whist, they come.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Come, meet me boldly, come,
And let them come from hunting when they dare.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Has the best spirit.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Spirit? what a plague,
Shall a man fear Capriches? you forsooth
Must have your love come to ye , and when he comes,
Then you grow shamefaced, and he must not touch you:
But fie, my Father comes, and foe, my Aunt,
O it is a witty hearing, is it not think you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, pray thee do not mock her gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, you are even as wise a wooer too,
If she turn from you, you even let her turn,
And say; you do not love to force a Lady.
It is too much rudeness; gosh hat, what is a Lady?
Must she not be touched? what, is she copper think you?
And will not bide the touch stone? kiss her Vince,
If thou dost love me, kiss her.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Lady, now
I were too simple if I should not offer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O God sir, pray away, this man talks idly.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: How shay by that; now by that candle there,
Were I as Vince is, I would handle you
In ruftie tuftie wise, in your right kind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, you have made him a sweet beagle, have you not?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is the most true believer in himself:
Of all that sect of folly faith is his fault.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: So to her Vince, I give thee leave my lad,
Sweet were the words my mistress spake, when tears fell from her eyes.
Thus, as the Lion lies before his den,
Guarding his whelps, and streaks his careless limbs,
And when the Panther, Fox, or Wolf comes near,
He never deigns to rise, to fright them hence,
But only puts forth one of his stern paws,
And keeps his dear whelps safe, as in a hutch,
So I present his person, and keep mine.
Foxes, go by I put my terror forth,
Let all the world say what they can,
Her bargain best she makes,
That hath the wit to choose a man,
To pay for that he takes.
Dispatch sweet whelps the bug, the Duke comes strait:
O it is a grave old lover that same Duke,
And chooses Minions rarely, if you mark him.
The noble Medice, that man, that Bobbadilla.
That foolish knave, that hose and doublet stinkard.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: 'swounds my Lord, rise, let us endure no more.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: A little, pray my Lord, for I believe
We shall discover very notable knavery.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Alas how I am grieved and shamed in this.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Never care you Lord brother, there is no harm done.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But that sweet Creature, my good Lords sister,
Madam Cortezza, she, the noblest Dame
That ever any vein of honour bled;
There were a wife now, for my Lord the Duke
Had he the grace to choose her, but indeed.
To speak her true praise, I must use some study.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Now truly brother, I did ever think
This man the honestest man that ere you kept.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: So sister, so, because he praises you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay sir, but you shall hear him further yet.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Were not her head sometimes a little light,
And so unapt for matter of much weight,
She were the fittest, and the worthiest Dame
To leap a window, and to break her neck,
That ever was.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Gods pity, arrant knave,
I ever thought him a dissembling varlet.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Well, now my hearts be wary, for by this,
I fear the Duke is coming; I will go watch,
And give you warning:I commend me to ye .

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O fine phrase,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And very timely used.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What now sweet life, shall we resolve upon?
We never shall enjoy each other here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Direct you then my Lord, what we shall do,
For I am at your will, and will endure
With you, the cruellest absence, from the state
We both were born to , that can be supposed.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That would extremely grieve me, could myself
Only endure the ill, our hardest fates,
May lay on both of us; I would not care,
But to behold thy sufferance, I should die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How can your Lordship wrong my love so much,
To think the more woe I sustain for you,
Breeds not the more my comfort? I alas
Have no mean else, to make my merit even
In any measure, with your eminent worth.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Now must I exercise my timorous lovers,
Like fresh armed soldiers, with some false alarms,
To make them yare and wary of their foe
The boisterous bearded Duke: I will rush upon them
With a most hideous cry, the Duke, the Duke, the Duke,
Ha, have, have, wo ho, come again I say,
The Duke is not come i'faith.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Gods precious man,
What did you mean to put us in this fear?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O sir, to make you look about the more;
Nay, we must teach you more of this I tell you:
What, can you be too safe sir? what I say,
Must you be pampered in your vanities?
Ah, I do domineer and rule the roost.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Was ever such an Ingle? would to God,
(If it were not for ourselves ) my father saw him.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.l: Minion, you have your prayer, and my curse,
For your good Housewifery.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What says your Highness?
Can you endure these injuries any more?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No more, no more, advise me what is best,
To be the penance of my graceless son?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My Lord, no mean but death or banishment,
Can be fit penance for him: if you mean
To enjoy the pleasure of your love yourself.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Give him plain death my Lord, and then you are sure.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Death or his banishment, he shall endure,
For wreak of that joys exile I sustain.
Come, call our Guard, and apprehend him strait.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I have some Jewels then my dearest life,
Which with whatever we can get beside,
Shall be our means, and we will make escape.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'sblood, the Duke and all come now in earnest;
The Duke, by heaven, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nay, then i'faith
Your jest is too too stale.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Gods precious,
By these ten bones, and by this hat and heart,
The Duke and all comes, see,we are cast away.

body.stage: Enter Alphonso, Medice, Lasso, Cortezza, and Iulio.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Lay hands upon them all, pursue, pursue.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Stay thou ungracious girl.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Lord Medice,
Lead you our Guard, and see you apprehend
The treacherous boy, nor let him scape with life,
Unless he yield to his external exile.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It is princely said my Lord

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: And take my Usher.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let me go into exile with my Lord,
I will not live, if I be left behind .

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Impudent Damsel, wouldst thou follow him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is my husband, whom else should I follow?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Wretch, thou speakest treason to my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Yet love me Lady, and I pardon all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have a husband, and must love none else.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Despiteful Dame, I will disinherit him,
And thy good Father here shall cast off thee,
And both shall feed on air, or starve, and die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If this be justice, let it be our dooms:
If free and spotless love in equal years,
With honours unimpaired deserve such ends,
Let us approve what justice is in friends.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: You shall I swear: sister, take you her close
Into your chamber, lock her fast alone,
And let her stir nor speak with anyone .

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: She shall not brother: come Niece, come with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heaven save my love, and I will suffer gladly.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Haste Iulio, follow thou my sons pursuit,
And will Lord Medice not to hurt nor touch him,
But either banish him, or bring him back:
Charge him to use no violence to his life.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: O Nature! how alas
Art thou and Reason thy true guide opposed?
More bane thou takest, to guide Sense, led amiss,
Than being guided, Reason gives thee bliss.

body.stage: Enter Cynanche, Beneuenius, Ancula, Strozza hauing the Arrow head.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Now see good Doctor, it was no frantic fancy,
That made my tongue presage this head should fall
Out of my wounded side the seventh day;
But an inspired rapture of my mind,
To my Creator, in whom I fore-saw
(Like to an Angel) this divine event.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So is it plain, and happily approved,
In a right christian president, confirming
What a most sacred medicine Patience is,
That with the high thirst of our souls, clear fire
Exhausts corporeal humour; and all pain,
Casting our flesh off, while we it retain.

sp.speaker: Cy.
sp.l: Make some religious vow then my dear Lord,
And keep it in the proper memory,
Of so Celestial and free a grace.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sweet wife, thou restest my good Angel still,
Suggesting by all means, these ghostly counsels.
Thou weariest not thy husbands patient ears,
With motions for new fashions in attire,
For change of Jewels, pastimes, and nice cates,
Nor studiest eminence, and the higher place
Amongst thy consorts, like all other Dames:
But knowing more worthy objects appertain
To every woman that desires to enjoy
A blessed life in marriage: thou contemnest
Those common pleasures, and pursuest the rare,
Using thy husband in those virtuous gifts:
For which, thou first didst choose him, and thereby
Cloyest not with him, but lovest him endlessly.
In reverence of thy motion then, and zeal
To that most sovereign power, that was my cure.
I make a vow to go on foot to Rome,
And offer humbly in Saint Peters Temple,
This fatal Arrow head: which work, let none judge
A superstitious Rite, but a right use,
Proper to this peculiar instrument,
Which visibly resigned to memory,
Through every eye that sees, will stir the soul
To Gratitude and Progress, in the use
Of my tried patience which in my powers ending,
Would shut the example out of future lives.
No act is superstitious, that applies
All power to God, devoting hearts, through eyes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Spoke with the true tongue of a Nobleman:
But now are all these excitations toys,
And Honour fats his brain with other joys.
I know your true friend, Prince Vincentio
Will triumph in this excellent effect
Of your late prophecy.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: O, my dear friends name
Presents my thoughts, with a most mortal danger,
To his right innocent life: a monstrous fact
Is now effected on him.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Where? or how?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I do not well those circumstances know,
But am assured, the substance is too true.
Come reverend Doctor, let us hearken out
Where the young Prince remains, and bear with you
Medicines to allay his danger: if by wounds,
Bear precious Balsam, or some sovereign juice;
If by fell poison, some choice Antidote,
If by black witchcraft, our good spirits and prayers
Shall exorcise the divelish wrath of hell,
Out of his princely bosom.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Where? where? where? where is my Lord uncle, my Lord my uncle?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Here is the ill tidings-bringer; what news now,
with thy unhappy presence?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: O my Lord, my Lord Vincentio, is almost killed by my Lord Medice.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: See Doctor, see, if my presage be true.
And well I know if he have hurt the Prince,
It is treacherously done, or with much help.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Nay sure he had no help, but all the Dukes Guard; and they set upon him indeed; and after he had defended himself, do ye see? he drew, and; having as good as wounded the Lord Medice almost, he strake at him, and missed him, do ye mark?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What tale is here? where is this mischief done?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: At Monks well, my Lord, I will guide you to him presently.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I doubt it not; fools are best guides to ill,
And mischiefs ready way lies open still.
Lead sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Quiet yourself, Niece; though your love be slain,
You have another that is worth two of him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is not possible; it cannot be
That heaven should suffer such impiety.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: It is true, I swear niece.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O most unjust truth!
I will cast myself down headlong from this Tower;
And force an instant passage for my soul,
To seek the wandering spirit of my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Will you do so Niece? That I hope you will not,
And yet there was a Maid in Saint Marks street,
For such a matter did so; and her clothes
Flew up about her so as she had no harm:
And grace of God your clothes may fly up too,
And save you harmless; for your cause and hers
Are even as like as can be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would not scape;
And certainly I think the death is easy.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: O it is the easiest death that ever was,
Look Niece, it is so far hence to the ground.
You should be quite dead, long before you felt it.
Yet do not leap Niece.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will kill myself
With running on some sword; or drink strong poison;
Which death is easiest I would fain endure.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sure Cleopatra was of the same mind,
And did so; she was honoured ever since,
Yet do not you so Niece.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wretch that I am; my heart is soft and faint;
And trembles at the very thought of death,
Though thoughts ten-fold more grievous do torment it;
I will feele death by degrees; and first deform
This my accursed face with ugly wounds,
That was the first cause of my dear loves death.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That were a cruel deed; yet Adelasia;
In Pettis Palace of Petit pleasure,
For all the world, with such a knife as this
Cut off her cheeks, and nose, and was commended
More than all Dames that kept their faces whole;
O do not cut it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fie on my faint heart,
It will not give my hand the wished strength;
Behold the just plague of a sensual life,
That to preserve itself in Reasons spite,
And shun deaths horror, feels it ten times more.
Unworthy women, why do men adore
Our fading Beauties, when their worthiest lives,
Being lost for us, we dare not die for them?
Hence hapless Ornaments that adorned this head:
Disorder ever these entering carls
And leave my beauty like a wilderness,
That never man's eye more may dare to invade.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I will tell you Niece; and yet I will not tell you,
A thing that I desire to have you do.
But I will tell you only what you might do,
Cause I would pleasure you in all I cud.
I have an Ointment here, which we Dames use,
To take off hair when it does grow too lowe
Upon our foreheads, and that for a need,
If you should rub it hard upon your face,
Would blister it, and make it look most vildly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Give me that Aunt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Give it you virgin? that were well indeed:
Shall I be thought to tempt you to such matters?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: None (of my faith) shall know it: gentle Aunt,
Bestow it on me, and I will ever love you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Gods pity, but you shall not spoil your face.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not then indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why then Niece take it:
But you shall swear you will not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I swear.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What, do you force it from me? Gods my dear,
Will you misuse your face so? what, all over?
Nay, if you be so desperate, I will be gone --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fade hopeless beauty, turn the ugliest face
The ever Aethiop, or a frightful fiend
Showed in the amazed eye of profaned light:
See precious Love, if thou be it in air,
And canst break darkness, and the strongest Towers,
With thy dissolved intellectual powers,
See a worse torment suffered for thy death,
Than if it had extended his black force,
In seven-fold horror to my hated life.
Smart precious ointment, smart, and to my brain
Sweat thy envenomed fury, make my eyes
Burn with thy sulphur like the lakes of hell,
That fear of me may shiver him to dust,
That eat his own child with the jaws of lust --

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I wonder how far they pursued my Sonne,
That no return of him or them appears,
I fear some hapless accident is chanced,
That makes the news so loath to pierce mine ears.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: High heaven vouchsafe no such effect succeed
Those wretched causes that from my house flow,
But that in harmless love all acts may end.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: What shall I do? Alas I cannot rule
My desperate Niece, all her sweet face is spoiled,
And I dare keep her prisoner no more:
See, see, she comes frantic and all undressed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tyrant! behold how thou hast used thy love,
See, thief to Nature, thou hast killed and robbed,
Killed what myself killed , robbed what makes thee poor.
Beauty (a Lovers treasure) thou hast lost
Where none can find it; all a poor Maids dowers
Thou hast forced from me: all my joy and hope.
No man will love me more; all Dames excel me,
This ugly thing is now no more a face,
Nor any vile form in all Earth resembled,
But thy foul tyranny; for which all the pains
Two faithful Lovers feele, that thus are parted,
All joys they might have felt, turn all to pains;
All a young virgin thinks she does endure,
To lose her love and beauty; on thy heart
Be heaped and pressed down till thy soul depart.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hall Liege, your son is dangerously hurt.
Lord Medice contemning your command,
By me delivered, as your Highness willed,
Set on him with your Guard; who struck him down ;
And then the coward Lord, with mortal wounds,
And slavish insolency, ploughed up his soft breast;
Which barbarous fact in part is laid on you,
For first enjoying it, and foul exclaims
In pity of your son, your subjects breathe
Against your unnatural fury; amongst whom
The good Lord Strozza desperately raves ,
And vengeance for his friends injustice craves.
See where he comes burning in zeal of friendship.

body.stage: Enter Srozza, Vincentio brought in a chaire, Beneuenius, Pogio, Cynanche with a guard, Strozza before & Medice

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Where is the tyrant? let me strike his eyes
Into his brain, with horror of an object.
See Pagan Nero, see how thou hast ripped
Thy better bosom; rooted up that flower,
From whence thy now spent life should spring anew,
And in him killed, (that would have bred thee fresh)
Thy mother and thy father.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Good friend cease.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What hag with child of Monster, would have nursed
Such a prodigious longing? But a father
Would rather eat the brawn out of his arms
Then glut the mad worm of his wild desires
With his dear issues entrails.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Honoured friend;
He is my father, and he is my Prince,
In both whose rights he may command my life.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What is a father? turn his entrails gulfs
To swallow children, when they have begot them?
And what is a Prince? Had all been virtuous men,
There never had been Prince upon the earth,
And so no subject; all men had been Princes:
A virtuous man is subject; to no Prince,
But to his soul and honour; which are laws,
That carry Fire and Sword within themselves
Never corrupted never out of rule;
What is there in a Prince? That his least lusts
Are valued at the lives of other men,
When common faults in him should prodigies be,
And his gross dotage rather loathed than soothed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: How thick and heavily my plagues descend?
Not giving my mazed powers a time to speak:
Pour more rebuke upon me worthy Lord,
For I have guilt and patience for them all:
Yet know, dear son, I did forbid thy harm:
This Gentleman can witness, whom I sent
With all command of haste to interdict:
This forward man in mischief; not to touch thee:
Did I not Iulio? utter naught but truth.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: All your guard heard, my Lord, I gave your charge,
With loud and violent iterations.
After all which, Lord Medice cowardly hurt him.

sp.speaker: The Guard.
sp.l: He did my Princely Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Believe then son,
And know me pierced as deeply with thy wounds:
And pardon virtuous Lady that have lost
The dearest treasure proper to your sex.
Aye me, it seems by my unhappy means!
O would to God, I could with present cure
Of these unnatural wounds; and moaning right
Of this abused beauty, ijoin you both,
(As last I left you) in eternal nuptials.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: My Lord, I know the malice of this man,
Not your unkind consent hath used us thus.
And since I make no doubt I shall survive
These fatal dangers; and your grace is pleased,
To give free course to my unwounded love;
It is not this outward beauties ruthful loss,
Can any thought discourage my desires:
And therefore, dear life, do not wrong me so,
To think my love the shadow of your beauty,
I woo your vertues, which as I am sure
No accident can alter or impair;
So, be you certain naught can change my love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know your honourable mind my Lord,
And will not do it that unworthy wrong,
To let it spend her forces in contending
(Spite of your sense) to love me thus deformed:
Love must have outward objects to delight him,
Else his content will be too grave and sour.
It is enough for me my Lord, you love,
And that my beauties sacrifice redeemed
My sad fear of your slaughter. You first loved me
Closely for beauty; which being withered thus.
Your love must fade; when the most needful rights
Of Fate, and Nature, have dissolved your life,
And that your love must needs be all in soul,
Then will we meet again: and then (dear Loue)
Love me again; for then will beauty be
Of no respect with loves eternity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Nor is it now; I wooed your beauty first
But as a lover: now as a dear husband,
That title and your vertues bind me ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas, that title is of little force
To stir up men's affections: when wives want
Outward excitements, husbands loves grow scant.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Assist me Heaven, and Art, give me your Mask,
Open thou little store-house of great Nature,
Use an Elixir drawn through seven years fire,
That like Medeas Cauldron, can repair
The ugliest loss of living temperature:
And for this princely pair of virtuous Turtles,
Be lavish of thy precious influence
Lady, to attone your honourable strife,
And take all let from your loves tender eyes.
Let me for ever hide this stain of Beauty,
With this recureful Mask; here be it fixed
With painless operation; of itself,
(Your beauty having brooked three days eclipse)
Like a dissolved cloud it shall fall off.
And your fair looks regain their freshest rays:
So shall your Princely friend, (if heaven consent)
In twice your suffered date renew recure,
Let me then have the honour to conjoin
Your hands, conformed to your constant hearts.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Grave Beneuenius, honourable Doctor,
On whose most sovereign sculapian hand,
Fame with her richest miracles attends,
Be fortunate, as ever heretofore,
That we may quite thee both with gold and honour,
And by thy happy means, have power to make
My Sonne, and his much injured love amends,
Whose well proportioned choice we now applaud,
And bless all those that ever furthered it.
Where is your discreet Usher my good Lord,
The special furtherer of this equal match?

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.l: Brought after by a couple of your Guard.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Let him be fetched, that we may do him grace.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I will fetch him my Lord: away, you must not go: O here
He comes; O master Usher, I am sorry for you, you must presently be chopped in pieces.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Wo to that wicked Prince that ere I saw him.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Come, come, I gull you master Usher, you are like to be the Dukes Minion man; do ye think I would have been seen in your company, if you had been out of favour? Here is my friend master Usher, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Give me your hand friend, pardon us I pray,
We much have wronged your worth, as one that knew the
fitness of this match above ourselves .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Sir, I did all things for the best, I swear,
And you must think I would not have been gulled,
I know what is fit sir; as I hope you know now:
Sweet Vince, how farest thou, be of honoured cheer.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Vince does he call him? O Fool, dost thou call
The Prince Vince, like his equal?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: O my Lord, Alas
You know not what has past twixt us two;
Here in thy bosom I will lie sweet Vince,
And die if thou die; I protest by heaven.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: I know not what this means.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord:
But sure he saw the fitness of the match,
With freer and more noble eyes then we.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Why I saw that as well as he my Lord; I knew it was a foolish match betwixt you two; did nor you think so my Lord Vincentio? Lord uncle, did not I say at first of the Duke; will his Antiquity never leave his Iniquity?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Go to, too much of this; but ask this Lord,
If he did like it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Who, my Lord Medice?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Lord Stinkard Man, his name is; ask him Lord Stinkard, did you like the match? say.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: My Lord Stinkard, did you like the match betwixt the Duke, and my Lady Margaret?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Presumptuous Sycophant, I will have thy life.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Unworthy Lord, put up: thirstest thou more blood?
Thy life is fittest to be called in question.
For thy most murtherous cowardice on my son ;
Thy forwardness to every cruelty
Calls thy pretended Noblesse in suspect.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Noblesse my Lord? set by your princely favour,
That gave the lustre to his painted state,
Who ever viewed him but with deep contempt,
As reading vileness in his very looks?
And if he prove not son of some base drudge,
Trimmed up by Fortune, being disposed to jest
And dally with your state, then that good Angel,
That by divine relation spake in me,
Fore-telling these foul dangers to your son,
And without notice brought this reverend man
To rescue him from death: now fails my tongue,
And I will confess, I do him open wrong.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: And so thou dost; and I return all note
Of infamy or baseness on thy throat:
Damn me my Lord, if I be not a Lord.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: My Liege, with all desert, even now you said
His life was duly forfeit, for the death
Which in these barbarous wounds he sought your son ;
Vouchsafe me then his life, in my friends right,
For many ways I know he merits death;
Which, (if you grant) will instantly appear,
And that I feele with some rare miracle.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: His life is thine Lord Strozza, Give him death.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What my Lord,
Will your grace cast away an innocent life?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Villain thou liest, thou guilty art of death
A hundred ways, which now I will execute.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Recall your word my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: O my dear Liege, but that my spirit prophetic
Hath inward feeling of such sins in him,
As ask the forfeit of his life and soul,
I would, before I took his life, give leave
To his confession, and his penitence:
O, he would tell you most notorious wonders,
Of his most impious state; but life and soul
Must suffer for it in him, and my hand
Forbidden is from heaven to let him live,
Till by confession he may have forgiveness.
Die therefore monster.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: O be not so uncharitable sweet friend,
Let him confess his sins, and ask heaven pardon.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: He must not Princely friend, it is heavens justice
To plague his life and soul, and here is heavens justice.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: O save my life my Lord.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.l: Hold good Lord Strozza,
Let him confess the sins that heaven hath told you,
And ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Let me good my Lord,
And I will confess what you accuse me of;
Wonders indeed, and full of damned deserts.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I know it, and I must not let thee live
To ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: But you shall my Lord,
Or I will take his life out of your hand.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: A little then I am content my Liege:
Is thy name Medice?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No my Noble Lord,
My true name is Mendice.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Mendice? see,
At first a Mighty scandal done to Honour.
Of what country art thou?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Of no Country, I,
But born upon the Seas, my mother passing
Twixt Zast and Venice.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Where wert thou christened?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I was never christened,
But being brought up with beggars, called Mendice.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Strange, and unspeakable.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: How camest thou then
To bear that port thou didst, entering this Court?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My lord when I was young, being able limbed,
A Captain of the Gypsies entertained me,
And many years I lived a loose life with them:
At last I was so favoured, that they made me
The King of Gypsies; and being told my fortune
By an old Sorceress, that I should be great
In some great Princes love, I took the treasure
Which all our company of Gypsies had
In many years, by several stealths collected,
And leaving them in wars, I lived abroad,
With no less show than now: and my last wrong
I did to Noblesse, was in this high Court.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Never was heard so strange a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Didst thou not cause me to be shot in hunting?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I did my Lord, for which, for heavens love pardon.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Now let him live my Lord, his bloods least drop
Would stain your Court, more than the Sea could cleanse:
His soul is too foul to expiate with death.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Hence then, be ever banished from my rule,
And live a monster, loathed of all the world.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I will get boys and bait him out of the Court my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Do so I pray thee, rid me of his sight.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Come on my Lord Stinckerd, I will play Fox, Fox, come out of thy hole with you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I will run and hide me from the sight of heaven .

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Fox, Fox, go out of thy hole; a two legged Fox,
A two legged Fox.

sp.speaker: Beue.
sp.l: Never was such an accident disclosed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Let us forget it honourable friends,
And satisfy all wrongs with my sons right,
In solemn marriage of his love and him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Highness honoured Doctor,
The Balsam you infused into my wounds,
Hath eased me much, and given me sudden strength
Enough to assure all danger is exempt,
That any way may let the general joy,
My Princely Father speaks of in our nuptials.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Which my dear Sonne shall with thy full recovery
Be celebrate in greater Majesty,
Than ever graced our greatest Ancestry.
Then take thy love, which heaven with all joys blessed,
And make ye both mirrors of happiness.
